share.comment: The practice of charging young people as adults gained momentum in America in the 1990s, as youth crime spiked. Between 1990 and 2010 the number of juveniles in adult jails went up by nearly 230%. Yet young people are easier to rehabilitate than older offenders, so programmes that keep them out of prison in the first place can save money and reduce crime http://econ.st/1CoNY61

share.comment: Seismologists tend to greet the idea that some animals know when an earthquake is coming with a sizeable degree of scepticism. Though reports of odd animal behaviour before a quake date back at least as far as ancient Greece, the data are all anecdotal. However, data just published in Physics and Chemistry of the Earth, are not just anecdotal http://econ.st/19F0PXC

content.description: Animals really may be able to sense when a tremor is about to happen
content.title: The chickens are restless

values.comment: Great goals, but I wonder if these goals are driving change or merely statistical measures of natural economic forces at work. We could test it by focusing on the "phasing out fossil fuel subsidies" goal, then reinvesting all the money saved on the remaining goals.
Good intentions gone wildly . . . not 'bad', but silly. Where was Occam's razor?

share.comment: When the Millennium Development Goals were adopted in 2000 they seemed Utopian. But the most important one was achieved five years early. This was to halve, by 2015, the share of people globally living on under $1.25 a day, which was 36% in 1990. Most progress was in China, where the proportion fell from 60% in 1990 to 12% in 2010 http://econ.st/19wMUDg
